sentence: As such, personalized learning systems can be thought of as a collection of three elements: 1) personalization; 2) digital technology; and 3) education.
The combination of personalization and digital technology goes hand in hand with measurement, analytics, and the collection and processing of big data.
The combination of personalization and digital technology goes hand in hand with measurement, analytics, and the collection and processing of big data.

In the domain of learning, as discussed here, analytics are often referred to as learning analytics (Bellini et al., 2019) and data collection can be referred to as educational data mining (Avella et al., 2016).

How the collection, processing, and use of educational data is performed is of key importance to the learning system as a whole; and thus for our moral analysis.
Finally, it should be emphasized that another important component of personalized learning systems are learning theories (Bulger, 2016).
Personalized learning systems can hence not be simply described as a technology.

Authors in the debate on the future of education have either a narrower conception of education as the acquisition of skills, especially those that will enable people to thrive in their professional lives), or a broader conception of education as the preparation for adulthood in all its facets, including having professional skills as well as leading a happy and healthy life, and being a responsible citizen.

Authors in the debate on the future of education have either a narrower conception of education as the acquisition of skills, especially those that will enable people to thrive in their professional lives), or a broader conception of education as the preparation for adulthood in all its facets, including having professional skills as well as leading a happy and healthy life, and being a responsible citizen.

By analyzing the morality of the promises and expectations about personalized learning systems, we contribute to the debate on the future of education, as well as the role of digital technology within this future.

23.4.2	Autonomy

However, others point to the potential harms for autonomy that personalized learning creates because it steers all learners to predefined goals, instead of allowing them to discover their own values (Knox et al., 2020).
If one adopts the narrow conception of education as preparing children for their professional lives, one may not see many harms to autonomy.

If on the other hand one adopts the broader conception of education as preparing children for all facets of adulthood, such as helping them to achieve prosperous and flourishing lives, one could argue that in order to become fully autonomous in the Aristotelean sense, education should help the student discover what a full and flourishing life means to her.

23.4.4	Human dignity
The opposite of human dignity can be humiliation are using people as means.
Personalized learning systems are at risk of violating human dignity in three ways.
When students make use of personalized system in the context of a classroom or a course, they are likely to compare their speed of going through the material and their marks with others.
When students make use of personalized system in the context of a classroom or a course, they are likely to compare their speed of going through the material and their marks with others.

When certain students find out they are among the slower or lower performers, or they find out that their best effort is not sufficient for maintaining the speed of their classmates, this can be humiliating for the student.
Techniques to motivate Third and finally, many personalized learning systems make use of rewards that aim to reinforce desired behavior.
While such mechanisms may increase student retention, they are a poor and empty substitute for real recognition.
These rewards systems are a shallow form of praise that does not connect with a student’s self-chosen reasons for following education.
Instead, it seeks to capture the student’s attention by appealing to their more basic instincts.

However, if a group of students collaborates guided by a digital system, and the students have access to each other’s information, this creates a potential threat to relational privacy.
Relational privacy “consists in people voluntarily limiting their knowledge of each other as they interact in a wide variety of social and commercial roles” (Sloan & Warner, 2016, p 347).

Another relation that needs consideration is the relation between teacher and student.
Personalized learning systems can change educational practices and as such affect student-teacher relations.
For example, when students follow their own learning paths, directed by artificial intelligence, the teacher’s relation with the student becomes more distant.
When the relation between teacher and student becomes more distant, it might be considered appropriate to give the teacher less information of the student.

23.5	Justice
23.5	Justice
We should make a distinction between two levels of harm to human capabilities.
First, it can be said that personalized learning systems inflict harm on people in their capacity as learners.
Hereby, the learning experience becomes more individualistic (McRae, 2013) and neglective of the social dimension of teaching (Bulger, 2016).
We should make a distinction between two levels of harm to human capabilities.
First, it can be said that personalized learning systems inflict harm on people in their capacity as learners.
Whereas standard education is performed in a classroom with a teacher, personalized learning system is conducted behind a screen.
Hereby, the learning experience becomes more individualistic (McRae, 2013) and neglective of the social dimension of teaching (Bulger, 2016).
Second, as the purpose of education is to prepare young people for their later lives, personalized learning systems could potentially inflict harm on people in their later lives.

If one adopts the narrow conception of education as preparing children for their professional lives, this second level is concerned with the infliction of harm to the capabilities of people in the capacity as workers.

If on the other hand one adopts the broader conception of education as preparing children for all facts of adulthood, this second level is concerned with the infliction of harm to potentially all capabilities.
Second, as the purpose of education is to prepare young people for their later lives, personalized learning systems could potentially inflict harm on people in their later lives.

If on the other hand one adopts the broader conception of education as preparing children for all facts of adulthood, this second level is concerned with the infliction of harm to potentially all capabilities.
23.5.2	Global Justice

In addition, personalized learning systems could be used to provide access to education for people in developing countries who have no, or limited access to schools (Zualkarnan, 2016).
In addition, personalized learning systems could be used to provide access to education for people in developing countries who have no, or limited access to schools (Zualkarnan, 2016).

While self-paced personalized learning may not be able to fully replace traditional or hybrid forms of education, it certainly has the potential to be an asset for those who would otherwise not have access to education.
On the positive side, there is some evidence that the gap in performance between students from privileged and underprivileged backgrounds is smaller when personalized learning systems are used.
This finding can be attributed to the personalization that enables each student to learn at her own pace.

This is especially true if such an approach is combined with methods that stimulate students to learn from one another and have interest for each student’s particular set of knowledge.
